result.execSummary:
The defendant Derek W Moyer was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Def to undergo Alcohol and Drug Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommendations.
.

Def is not to consume or possess any alcohol or controlled substances without a prescription from licensed physician, with random screenings.
.

Pay Crime Lab and Drug Assessment fee (see 'other' above for amount)

  If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendent in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

  Pay DOC Supervision fees.

  Undergo any other assessments or evaluations deemed appropriate by PO and follow thru with any treatment recommendations.

Credit for 22 days if probation revoked.
.

supervisions.notes:
To be served in custody, without release.  The last 45 days can be served on Electronic Monitoring with Justice Support Services

Any unpaid restitution and Court financial obligations are converted to a Civil Judgment.  PO to provide Order
.
Consecutive to: Consecutive to the sentence in La Crosse Co case 14CF3
.

CRT:  I am going to allow you back on EM.  I am going to add another week until you can be released to EM.  If your release date is 9-27-15, I'm adding another week to that date
Hearing at 09-23-2015 02:30 pm
revoked

3 Request for Modification or Change in Sentence filed in 14CF3
EML: denied
from PO Jennifer Noll    re: Sentencing after Revocation

10 am Def in court w/ Atty Eric S. Sanford.  Def in custody.  Jessica Skemp appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
The 'State is in compliance with victim notification requirements.  Skemp sites minor corrections to the violation summary.  Asks for consecutive sentences.  The recommendations don't take into account a number of factors; hIs previous criminal history, repeater status, and read-ins... Sanford asks for a sentence to allow him to get through the things he has going on...  Asks the Court to go along with the sentence structure.  Moyer comments.  Court comments.
SENTENCES:
14CF-3 - Counts 3 - 5 mos CJ; Count 4 - 5 mos CJ - consecutive w/206 days credit
14CF-211 - Count 1 - 4 mos CJ - consecutive to 14CF-3  The last 45 days can be served on em
14CM-579 - Count 1 - 10 days CJ - concurrent to 14CF-3
14CM-860 - Count 1 - 2 mos CJ consecutive to 14CF-3  can be served on
Total of 16 mos CJ.  The remaining time in custody can be served in La Crosse Co. or Monroe Co.
Any fees or restitution can be converted to a civil judgment.

Appeal rights advised.
